baseline_groups.claim_summary: Elasticity of climate damages with respect to temperature (power-law exponent d2): OLS of log damages on log temperature using Howard & Sterner (2017) meta-analysis data (N=43). Table 1 in the paper.
baseline_groups.expected_sign_rationale: Higher temperatures should increase climate damages; the paper estimates d2=1.88>0, indicating convex damages.
baseline_groups.reproduction_notes: All five parameters (coefficient, SE, N, R-squared, p-value) match the reported Table 1 values at reported precision.
notes: Single baseline group; this is the only reduced-form regression in the paper.
Design spec (design/cross_sectional_ols/estimator/ols) and weights/unweighted spec are mechanically identical to baseline.
rc/controls/sets/study_characteristics_basic is numerically identical to rc/controls/progression/study_type (both use Market+Grey+Preindustrial). Both retained as planned in the surface.

global_notes: No edits to baseline-group assignments relative to the surface. The surface defined a single group G1 and all 42 rows in specification_results.csv are assigned to G1, which is correct.

Three exploration specs (explore/form/outcome/level, explore/form/model/levels_quadratic, explore/preprocess/treatment/include_zero_damage_obs) were correctly excluded from specification_results.csv per the surface contract.

The quadratic treatment specs (rc/form/model/quadratic_treatment, rc/joint/outlier_form/drop_weitzman_quadratic) report the coefficient on the linear logt term with logt^2 included. This preserves the baseline claim object (the focal coefficient is still the logt elasticity), though the interpretation changes in the presence of the quadratic term. These are retained as core.
